newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnian Croat leader condemns mosque attack.
newsitem.headline: Bosnian Croat leader condemns mosque attack.

text.p: The Croat president of Bosnia's shaky Moslem-Croat federation on Monday condemned a bomb attack on a mosque, calling it an attempt to poison inter-communal relations.

Local media said a mosque near the town of Tomislavgrad in Croat-held western Bosnia was badly damaged in a bomb explosion on Saturday night. It was the only remaining Islamic house of worship in a region dominated by Croat nationalists.

The incident was the latest in a tit-for-tat series of attacks on religious buildings in the federation, touched off in part by a February 10 Croat police assault on Moslem pilgrims in Mostar in which one person was shot dead.

"The planting of an explosive device in a mosque in Stipanici, in Tomislavgrad municipality, was an act of violence that we strongly condemn," federation president Kresimir Zubak said in a statement carried by Croat media.

"This was an insult to every honest person, to all religious communities and nations, and as such is contrary to the principles of Croat policy in Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Federation of Bosnia-Herzegovina," he said.
The federation comprises one half of postwar Bosnia and a Serb republic entity the other.

"Undoubtedly it was also an attempt to undermine all efforts being made to normalise relations between Croats and Bosniak Moslems and to hamper the implementation of peace and peaceful co-existence in the region."
Zubak called on police to investigate the bombing thoroughly and bring the perpetrators to justice.
The office of Bosnia's international peace coordinator, Carl Bildt, and the Sarajevo office of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe also condemned the bombing.
"It is extremely unhelpful. We do not want to see any sort of tit-for-tat attacks on religious buildings," OSCE-Bosnia spokesman David Foley told a news conference.
